channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: US Plans to Boost Soy Exports to Italy and Form New Task Force
item.description: Italy will increase its imports of US soybeans as part of a new effort to rebalance trade between the two countries, US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins told reporters Monday after meeting with her Italian counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

media:content.media:description: Soybeans ready for planting at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies.

item.title: EU to Accept Trump Universal Tariff But Seeks Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of the bloc’s exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates on key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, alcohol, semiconductors and commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Argentina Grew More Than Expected After Milei Lifts Controls
item.description: Argentina’s economy grew more than expected in April as President Javier Milei loosened some currency controls as part of a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: A customer pays with Argentine peso banknotes at a shop in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, April 14, 2025. Argentina reached a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund after President Javier Milei made sweeping changes to ease the nation's currency controls in a landmark moment for his government.

item.title: ECB Strategy Fixes Help Avoid ‘False Certainty,’ Lagarde Says
item.description: Tweaks to the European Central Bank’s strategy unveiled Monday will allow policymakers to deliver more nuanced communication in an increasing unpredictable world, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a news conference during the ECB Forum on Central Banking in Sintra, Portugal, on Monday, June 30, 2025. The global economy’s concussion from five months of Trump’s presidency is likely to feature when some of the world’s leading central bank chiefs discuss monetary policy in public at the ECB forum. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer’s Welfare Overhaul Hangs in Balance Ahead of Key Vote
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is girding for what could be the most consequential vote of his premiership, with Labour rebels warning that the government’s welfare overhaul still risks defeat despite huge concessions to push it through parliament.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer

item.title: Goldman Sachs Pulls Forward Fed Rate-Cut Forecast to September
item.description: Goldman Sachs pulled forward its forecast for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts, and is now calling for the central bank to resume reductions in September rather than December, as the inflationary effects of tariffs “look a bit smaller” than expected.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: Goldman Sachs Group on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Says Tariff Pass-Through May Be Slow, Persistent
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said tariff price increases may be incremental instead of a one-time bump, which could result in more persistent upward pressure on inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023. Bostic said policymakers have time to watch how the economy is evolving and be patient when it comes to interest-rate moves.

item.title: Kenyan Inflation Holds Steady at 3.8% as Water, Power Costs Ease
item.description: Kenya’s annual inflation rate flatlined in June helped by slower growth in utilities and housing prices.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Stormwater runoff on a street in the Mukuru area of Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024. Garbage blocks many drains and waterways in Nairobi, worsening the effects of flooding. Residents are breeding millions of flies to consume that waste and help keep streets and homes dry.

item.title: EU Seals New Trade Deal With Ukraine as Tariff-Free Regime Ends
item.description: The European Union reached a new trade arrangement with Ukraine to replace the special tariff-free regime that was put in place in the wake of Russia’s full-scale invasion.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Lyubov Pronina

media:content.media:description: A farmer collects collects grain from a combine harvester during a harvest in the Fastiv district of Kyiv region, Ukraine.

item.title: StoneX Intends to Acquire Units of Bank Mired in US Drug Claims
item.description: StoneX Group Inc. said it’s seeking to acquire US units of Mexican bank Intercam Banco SA, which last week was among three firms accused by the Trump administration of facilitating money laundering for drug traffickers.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Navarro

media:content.media:description: An Intercam branch in Mexico City on June 25, 2025.

item.title: Bessent Says He Wouldn't Boost Long-Term Bond Sales at Today's Rates
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent indicated it wouldn’t make sense for the government to ramp up sales of longer-term securities given where yields are today, though he held out hope that interest rates across maturities will be falling as inflation slows.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Sonali Basak

media:content.media:description: US Trerasury Secretary Scott Bessent comments on the outlook for the 10-year Treasury yield on "Bloomberg Open Interest."

item.title: US Tariff Pause Brings Little Cheer to Lesotho’s Textile Industry
item.description: A temporary pause on US tariffs has brought little relief to Lesotho’s textile industry, which has suffered layoffs and shuttered factories after orders from America dried up.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: A worker folds completed jeans at a textile factory in Maseru, Lesotho. Photographer: Roberta Ciuccio/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Australian Home Prices Climb, Fueled by Falling Borrowing Costs
item.description: Australian home prices climbed for a fifth straight month, fueled by the Reserve Bank’s two interest-rate cuts this year and expectations of more to come.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Newly built houses in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: India Remains Key Driver of Global Growth, RBI’s Malhotra Says
item.description: India’s central bank said the country remains a key driver of global economic growth as domestic inflation continues to align with its target.
item.dc:creator: Advait Palepu, Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), during a news conference in Mumbai, India, on Friday, June 6, 2025. India's central bank cut interest rates more than projected and unexpectedly reduced the cash reserve ratio for banks, providing a major liquidity boost to the economy as growth prospects dim and inflation subsides. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Tightens Steel Import Tariff Regime to Fend Off Cheap Imports
item.description: The UK will limit the growth of tariff-free steel imports to guard against a rush of products being redirected from the US.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Rolled steel.

item.title: German Inflation Unexpectedly Cools to Match ECB’s 2% Target
item.description: German inflation unexpectedly eased this month, matching the European Central Bank’s goal for the first time in almost a year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Langley

media:content.media:description: Visitors outside a store in Bremen. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Fine-Tunes Strategy to Cope With More Frequent Shocks
item.description: The European Central Bank tweaked the way it uses monetary policy to steer the economy, suggesting it will more carefully weigh risks to the inflation outlook as well as the tools it uses to deliver its 2% goal.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Euro sculpture.

item.title: Trump Deals Poised to Fall Short of Sweeping Trade Reforms
item.description: With just 10 days to go until President Donald Trump’s country-specific tariffs are set to resume, the White House appears poised to fall short of the sweeping global trade reforms it promised to achieve during the three months they were on hold.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jenny Leonard

item.title: China Home Sales Slump Persists as Calls Grow for More Stimulus
item.description: China’s home sales extended their slump in June, putting further strain on the economy and underscoring the impetus for fresh support measures.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Emma Dong

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings in Yuncheng, Shanxi Province. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Irish Government Must Widen Tax Base, Central Bank Warns
item.description: Ireland should broaden its tax base to ensure its budget protects long-term fiscal stability, the Central Bank of Ireland warned.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Makhlouf

item.title: Trump’s Disruption Unnerves Central Bankers in Sintra
item.description: I’m Craig Stirling, a senior editor in Frankfurt. Today we’re looking at the big highlight of the European Central Bank’s annual retreat in Portugal. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: The National Palace of Sintra on the skyline of Sintra, Portugal, on Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024. Record summer temperatures, exorbitant luxury hotel rates and overcrowded hot spots: Nothing is getting in the way of a European summer vacation. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

item.title: The Three Traits of Trade Deal-Making in Trump’s Second Term
item.description: With a tax-and-spending cut bill inching closer to passage and a 90-day pause on his most extreme tariffs poised to expire, the next 10 days are setting up to be potentially the most consequential of President Donald Trump’s second term so far.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: Swiss Sight Deposits Soar After SNB Introduced Zero Rate Regime
item.description: Sight deposits at the Swiss National Bank rose sharply after its reduction of borrowing costs to zero, as foreign banks moved cash to the institution to escape negative interest paid in the money market.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Swiss franc banknotes.

item.title: Italy Inflation Unexpectedly Holds Steady Below 2% ECB Goal
item.description: Italian inflation unexpectedly stayed unchanged in June, holding below the European Central Bank’s 2% target for a second month.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Italy.

item.title: ECB’s Guindos Sees ‘Almost Flat’ Growth in April-September Period
item.description: The euro-area economy is stalling because of the enormous and “brutal uncertainty” surrounding global trade policy, according to European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Luis de Guindos, vice president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, March 16, 2023. The European Central Bank went ahead with a planned half-point increase in interest rates but was silent on what may follow amid market turmoil that roiled Credit Suisse Group AG. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sticks to Stainless-Steel Levies Despite Indonesia Pain
item.description: China will press on with levy anti-dumping duties on imports of stainless-steel products, including from Indonesia, as it seeks to protect a domestic industry battered by persistent oversupply and trade uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Alfred Cang

media:content.media:description: Rolled stainless steel.

item.title: South Africa’s Kganyago Bolsters Case for Lower Inflation Target
item.description: South African Reserve Bank Governor Lesetja Kganyago reinforced his argument for adopting a lower inflation target, noting that the current goal hurts the rand and allows prices to march higher.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: Street vendors in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Swedish Retail Sales Drop Pressures Riksbank to Cut Again
item.description: Swedish retail sales fell the most in more than three decades last month, continuing a run of disappointing data and increasing pressure on the country’s central bank to lower rates again.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Stockholm. Photographer: Erik Flyg/Bloomberg

item.title: UK’s G7-Topping Growth Confirmed Before Tax and Tariffs Hit
item.description: The UK economy grew strongly in the first quarter of the year, official data confirmed Monday, as Britons spent more and saved less before the Labour government’s tax hikes and extra US tariffs came into effect.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: An employee works in the bonnet area of an Aston Martin DBX SUV.

item.title: US Profit Margins Face Key Risk From Tariffs, Goldman Strategists Say
item.description: US profit margins face a big test in the upcoming reporting season as investors assess the damage from President Donald Trump’s trade war, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: General Mills shares fell 5% last week as the food company warned of a tariff hit on its cost of goods sold.
